chapter.htmlHeader: How should I assess someone with suspected genital herpes simplex?
chapter.htmlStringContent:
• A history and examination is necessary in primary care (even if the person is being referred) to determine the likelihood of genital herpes and exclude other causes of genital ulceration. 
  • Take a brief sexual history, and ask about:
    • Age — there is an increased risk in those aged under 25 years.
    • Previous sexually transmitted infections (STIs).
    • A new sexual partner.
    • More than one sexual partner in the last year.
    • Current and previous sexual partners.
    • Use of barrier contraception.
  • Ask about the onset and duration of symptoms, including:
    • Presence of painful ulcers. 
    • Dysuria, vaginal or urethral discharge.
    • Malaise, or fever.
    • Whether similar symptoms have been experienced previously.
    • Partner's previous history of cold sores (transmission via oro-genital sexual activity).
  • Examine the person's external genitalia and surrounding skin (lesions are usually bilateral with signs of redness, blistering, and ulceration).
    • Lesions can also affect the vagina and cervix in women, and men who have sex with men may present with herpes proctitis.
    • There may also be tender bilateral inguinal lymphadenitis.
    • Atypical herpes lesions can look different from typical genital blisters and ulceration, with an appearance of fissures, patchy erythema, linear lesions or excoriations.
  • Take a swab from the base of a lesion (pop blister if necessary) for viral culture, or polymerase chain reaction (PCR), depending on local arrangements.
  • Also consider:
    • Screening for other STIs. For more information, see the CKS topic on Chlamydia - uncomplicated genital. 
    • The possibility of pregnancy, HIV, or immunosuppression.
    • Alternative diagnoses. For more information, see the section on differential diagnosis.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
CKS identified no national guidelines for assessing genital herpes in primary care. These recommendations are largely based on the British Association for Sexual Health and HIV (BASHH) UK national guideline for the management of anogenital herpes [BASHH, 2014], a joint guideline with the Royal College of General Practitioners Sexually transmitted infections in primary care [RCGP, 2013], the British medical Journal (BMJ) best practice guide Herpes simplex infection [BMJ Best Practice, 2016], the New Zealand Herpes Foundation (NZHF) Guidelines for the management of genital herpes in New Zealand [NZHF, 2015], expert opinion in a narrative review Genital herpes [Gnann, 2016], and what CKS consider good clinical practice.

Diagnostic testing for HSV [BASHH, 2014]

  • If it is necessary to diagnose genital herpes in primary care, the confirmation and typing of the infection, by direct detection of HSV in genital lesions, is essential for diagnosis, prognosis, counselling, and management.
  • Nucleic acid amplification test (NAAT) methods are the test of choice.
    • NATT DNA detection by polymerase chain reaction (PCR) increases HSV detection rates by 11–71% compared with viral culture.
    • Viral culture has a specificity of nearly 100%, but this is influenced by virus shedding, the quality of specimens, storage of samples, and transport conditions. 
    • HSV culture misses approximately 30% of PCR positive samples, most significantly in people presenting with late or with mild recurrent disease.
